>>33869992
>My philosophy resembles closest that of RAW's "model agnosticism", boiling down to something like "no belief or disbelief only experience."
I used to think that way too. Something changed when I started respecting other people's experience rather than just my own. Now since it is 2nd hand information, a lot more skepticism and sifting through information is required. Now that I'm open to ancient wisdom, especially things that are common to many religions/magic systems through comparative analysis. Now, does that mean that the common parts are necessarily true? No, it could just be archetypes and collective unconsciousness, stuff like that. But that commonality still tells us something, even if it's just "Lots of cultures have the same dreams about X topic".

>Have you ever been poked by a spring or something while you were sleeping, and a corresponding effect takes place in your dream until the discomfort awakens you?
> I can't rule out my body just loudly making up a dream about "oh man oh man my heart my liver oh man what's going on this fucking sucks oh man oh man oh man"
Yeah, I think that could explain it.
>one belongs to the "mind" and one the body, and both take a part in composing your dreams.
Yeah that makes sense. Your experience doesn't exactly seem like an afterlife.

The problem is basically every religion in the world said "Yeah, there's an afterlife". I'm not sure why you don't believe in an afterlife, or perhaps you explicitly believe there is no afterlife. If you just go off your own experience while denying others (especially if the testimony is so unanimous and numerous), isn't that just a soft form of solipsism? My experiences are real, yours are not. I think listening to other people (with some skepticism) just makes sense. Imagine how smart you would be if you couldn't read and had no one to teach you anything. You might be a rather smart cave man, but nothing more.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33870070
>So, that is to say, I don't really "believe" in "convincing," you know?
>Allowing yourself to be "convinced" is how you stray from the path of Truth, and I think Truth is the only god worth worshipping.
Yeah I also think Truth with a capital T is important, but love is an act of (unifying) knowledge. You can't love someone you don't know, and loving someone will make you know them more. Both in the mental/metaphorical sense and the biblical/physical sense. That's why sex is called "knowing" in the bible. Love is a path to enlightenment. This is stuff I'm getting from the perennial philosophy by aldous huxley.
I'm not sure how you can experience truth unless you do, at some point, let your guard down and believe something. Love also involves letting your guard down.
And love obviously requires other people for you to love. And that would involve listening to them.

I used to be a rational skeptical logical atheist and didn't believe in magic/god at all. That was a long time ago, but I'm still trying to listen to people more.
> I can just as easily ascribe it to spiritual trickery or aliens or genies or etc etc.
I don't think that's entirely inconsistent with an afterlife. Many people thought it was elves, or spirits, or whatever. Spirits are aliens, just from another dimension rather than a different planet. If you believe in non-human intelligences that speak to people on the verge of death, then I think you're like 95% of the way to believing in an afterlife.
I mean, if it's real, then it would be actual. There would be some inner mechanics, some dynamics in its process, some rules it follows. Spirits being involved doesn't surprise me.

>What are your more interesting recommendations. What's the last book you've read?
Hmm, an interesting recommendation. Let's go with Religion and Nothingness by Keiji Nishitani. Haven't read it yet, but you might like it. It's a pure philosophy/theology if I recall correctly.

This is the God name of Saturn
Saturn is boundaries of our reality
The terrible mother who let's her child starve
Who kills by circumstance
The cold winter, not the blunt force
The elements
Saturn is the "Greater Malefic"

Love defeats machiavellianism, for a lover can neither be bought nor intimidated.

them from avenging their parents while explicitly consoling the officers blaming themselves for it, saying it was the right thing to do.
His speech received enthusiastic applause by the SS officers.
This was the meaning of the "Black Sun". It is a defeated Sun.

The more important feature of the star of David AS (i.e. seal of Solomon AS) is the two triangles. Eliphas Levi said that they represent the principle of as above so below. Man being mirrored in the cosmos and the cosmos being mirrored in man. You can also easily see how it would represent the nondual union of opposites and the divine translating itself or mirroring itself in the material world. Which seems a lot more likely to me than Jews secretly worshipping Saturn. If you look at planetary correspondences with the tree of life, Binah corresponds with Saturn, Chokmah with the Zodiac, Kether with nothing, and Malkuth with earth/the 4 elements (which you guys usually say means the cube). So the material world is on the bottom of the tree and you move up that through the spheres past Saturn and the Zodiac until you reach a philosophical, apophatic God who's somehow identical with you and everything else. It's falsehood but it's not Gnostic and it's closer to what most retards here believe than praying to a planet.

The Hindus have the same symbol btw, they call it the Shatkona, which has some of the same meanings I mentioned for the seal of Solomon AS.
>The Shatkona represents both the male and female form, as a symbol of the divine union of masculine and feminine and as a source of all creation; more specifically it is supposed to represent Purusha (the supreme being), and Prakriti (mother nature, or causal matter).

There are always exceptions in matters of people/culture, but the older traditions around the world were usually fearful.

The ancient Greeks for instance thought of a solar eclipse as an act of abandonment, a terrible crisis and an existential threat. It meant that the king would fall, that terrible misfortunes would rain down on the world, or that demons had swallowed the sun.

“If you do a worldwide survey of eclipse lore, the theme that constantly appears, with few exceptions, is it’s always a disruption of the established order,” said E. C. Krupp, of the Griffith Observatory in Los Angeles in a National Geographic article.

•Traders should respect that a traded read will be granted, as per an agreement of trade. Free readers have the option of picking their queries.
•Bullshit queries will get bullshit answers. Same for vague queries.
•Making an AQ (air query) by not addressing a reader, in particular, is possible but doesn't guarantee an answer.
•Avoid making the same query repeatedly and/or to different readers in a short period of time, as this may lead to more confusion.
•Provide feedback when applicable and be considerate to the reader. We're a growing community, many readers are starting and need to know what they are doing right or wrong. Let's help each other to improve.

>>33869217
Read The Book of Thoth. It takes a page out of traditional astrology. It relates to the 12th house, which says this:

The 12th house represents matters that are hidden, restrained, secret, incapable of action or of being fully understood. This can sometimes suggest conditions that are in a premature state of development and not yet recognised by the conscious mind (a recent horary on 'will I become pregnant?' showed the querent was already pregnant but unaware of it because of a separating trine from the Moon to Venus, ruler of the 5th, located in the 12th).
Traditionally, however, it is a wholly unfortunate house, associated with sad events, sorrow, anguish of mind, tribulation, captivity, imprisonment, persecution, hard labour, all manner of affliction and self-undoing. It represents places that are denied access to public view, particularly those concerned with seclusion or isolation, or where one is restricted from living a carefree life-style, such as institutions or prisons. Many sources attribute monasteries to the 12th house as places of isolation, but otherwise monks and nuns belong to the 9th house which represents religious concerns. It has rulership over scandals generally, personal fears and skeletons in the family closet.

I think it has to do with having the prime conditions. It happened for some reason but I don't really 'understand' why.

When we lived in San Francisco we would say "This is not real, there are no people, there is no world, there is no body". We would say it all day everyday. Some black lady came past us and said "shut up shut up shut up!" lol. We had weird experiences doing what we did. Were walking on California Street one morning and suddenly the street light and streetcar cable started shaking. IT was weird 'cause there was no earthquake as we felt no shaking and there was no news of an earthquake.

One time there was a 5.5 earthquake when we were in STarbucks. We saw the windows shake, the people around us noticed it but guess what? We didn't feel the the movement at all

Around the same time we were doing the mantras we found a 1.5 liter wine. We drank it and guess what? We didn't get a buzz at all lol

The best I can tell you is that you need to believe. We were very new agey at that time and believed in stuff like children. We experienced a lot of shit. It must have happened 'cause it was just the right conditions for it to happen. I loved living in Vancouver. I went hiking everyday and partied at night. I didn't like time pausing because I felt so lonely, it was surreal. I was only aware of my own consciousness.

Same deal with going from Vancouver Island and arriving in Vancouver 1 hr early. It made no sense based on the bus and ferry schedule lol. Like I said, probably perfect set of conditions set you up for interesting experiences. I hadn't expected the experiences, they just happened

I failed to mention when we were in Vancouver we were also doing mantras like "there is no space, there is no time" shit like that. We always said "this is not real" and it led to interesting shit. Like I said, we said our mantras all day, everyday

If you break it down, you can simply speak of electromagnetic phenomenon, and the nature of its electric (expansive) and magnetic (contractive) properties. Polarity comes into play. You can reframe life experiences as energetic reactions (a “negative” person being repulsed by a “positive” person’s presence, without a full understanding of why, etc). We know that energy is neither created nor destroyed, that all things are in motion, and that “matter” exists as both a particle and a wave. We know that infinity exists via pi, we can prove that our bodies can’t detect all that is (infrared, ultraviolet, sub/supersonic etc), and that to assume to know anything is folly.

We know that we come from what came before us. We know that the probability of us all existing here simultaneously in the ineffable infinity is so infinitesimally small that to believe we only have a one-and-done existence is infinitely less likely than the contrary.

You want proof? Where are your thoughts located? If you’re talking to yourself via thought, who’s listening? If you need eyes to see, how do you see in dreams? Quantum entanglement proves faster than light speed is possible, so what is it?

What if everything that exists is just one particle moving so incredibly “fast” beyond time and space that it creates a shared illusion that is incomprehensible to us all?

Do you really believe that we are random particles that just so happened to coincidentally assemble into what we are today? That would be like a tornado perfectly assembling a rocket ship by pure chance. And then everything else in existence.
